Award.AwardTitle: SBP: The Roots of Female Underrepresentation in STEM and Beyond: Exploring the Development of Gender Stereotypes about Intelligence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines the development of a key factor leading to women's underrepresentation in science and technology. Specifically, it examines the development of the cultural stereotype that links males but not females with intellectual brilliance and genius. Previous research has found that academic disciplines that are believed to require a "spark of genius" tend to have the largest gender gaps. Because many science fields are portrayed in such terms, the "brilliance = males" stereotype may be an important factor in explaining the persistent gender gap in these disciplines. The primary goal of this research is understanding how this stereotype is acquired over the course of development. Investigating the development of this stereotype will inform how the stereotype might steer capable young women away from pursuing careers in science and technology and may also inform the optimal timing of potential interventions to block its adverse effects.

This project consists of three studies to examine three crucial developmental issues. First, it investigates the development of children's knowledge of the cultural stereotype that males are more likely to be brilliant than females. Second, it investigates the development of gender differences in children's motivation to engage in activities portrayed as requiring high levels of intellectual aptitude. Finally, it investigates longitudinally whether internalizing the stereotype against females' intellectual abilities undermines young girls' subsequent motivation to engage in activities that are said to require brilliance and giftedness. This research explores the development of a set of processes that ultimately limit opportunities for women. As such, these studies will improve parents', educators', and policy-makers' ability to intervene at the root of the problem to promote greater gender equity in those domains of academia and industry in which women have traditionally been underrepresented.

This proposal is being co-funded by Developmental and Learning Sciences, Social Psychology, and Science of Broadening Participation within the Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences Directorate and by the Education and Human Resources Directorate's Core Research program and the Research on Gender in Science and Engineering program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research funded by this award examined the development of a key factor leading to women's underrepresentation in science and technology. Specifically, it examined the cultural stereotype that links men more than women with intellectual brilliance and genius (which we will refer to as the "brilliance = males" stereotype).

Previous research has found that field that are believed to require a "spark of genius" tend to have the largest gender gaps. Because many science fields are portrayed in such terms, the "brilliance = males" stereotype may be an important factor in explaining the persistent gender gap in these disciplines.

The goal of this research was to understand how these stereotypes are acquired over the course of children's development and how they relate to the gender disparities in educational and career trajectories observed in the US and worldwide.

The research supported by this award made substantial progress toward answering these questions. With respect to development, it suggested that cultural ideas about brilliance and gender are acquired early: By the age of 6, girls in our studies were less likely than boys to believe that members of their gender are "really, really smart." Also at age 6, girls began to shy away from novel activities said to be for children who are "really, really smart." However, the "brilliance = males" stereotype did not seem to apply equally to all racial/ethnic groups. Our research revealed instead that children learn to associate White men (vs. women), but not Black men (vs. women), with brilliance. In fact, children generally saw Black men as less brilliant than Black women.

Stereotypic associations often operate "under the radar"; people are often unaware that they hold such ideas. Indeed, research that we conducted using the well-known Implicit Association Test (IAT) suggested that people from all over the US associate the traits of brilliance and genius with men more than women at this implicit level as well. These implicit stereotypic associations were also found among children, reinforcing the notion that they are absorbed early in life.

In addition, the research conducted under this award contributed to our understanding of how the "brilliance = males" stereotype obstructs women's participation in science and other careers where brilliance is valued. In one series of studies, we found that the "brilliance = males" stereotype leads people to evaluate girls and women negatively in contexts where intellectual ability is emphasized (as in many science and engineering fields), depriving them of opportunities that are available to boys and men. Another set of studies conducted by the project team found that messages suggesting that a career requires brilliance undermine young women's own interest in that career, in part because they anticipate that they won't be accepted by, or fit in with, others in that career. Consistent with this idea, we also found that women (and particularly women from racial/ethnic groups traditionally underrepresented in academia) experience a heightened sense of being an impostor in fields that value brilliance, which is likely to affect their ability to persist and succeed in these fields.

To investigate the question of where children learn these gender stereotypes from, one of the projects conducted under the scope of this award investigated the language used on 95 popular children's television shows from 1960 to 2018. This study, which used cutting-edge analytic methods created for processing natural language, found a range of gender biases embedded in the language on these shows, highlighting them as a source of the stereotypic notions that contribute to the gender gaps observed in science and beyond.

In addition to its contribution to science (that is, its intellectual merit), the research supported by this award has the potential for broad societal impact because it suggests concrete steps that can be taken by members of many fields in science, engineering, and technology to increase the participation of women and other underrepresented groups. Given that (1) the "brilliance = males" stereotype is acquired as early as age 6, and (2) this stereotype has the power to influence the interests of young boys and girls, it seems important to target interventions at ages much younger than currently recommended. Additionally, our research suggests that successful interventions will need to include elements that forcefully and effectively negate the impact of these gendered notions about intellectual ability, which might otherwise undermine even the most well-intentioned efforts to broaden participation in science.

Beyond its contributions to scientific knowledge, this research provided valuable training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers. Since many of these trainees were themselves from backgrounds underrepresented in science, their involvement in this research facilitated their retention into the science pipeline, helping to make the future of science as diverse as American youth are.
